journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part A: Journal of Power and Energy

title-group.article-title: Parametric study and optimization of an ejector-expansion TRCC cycle integrated with a water purification system

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Mohaghegh Ardabili, Ardabil, Iran
2Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran

author-notes.corresp: M Yari, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, University of Mohaghegh Ardabili, Ardabil 179, Islamic Republic of Iran. Email: myari@uma.ac.ir

abstract.p: A combined cogeneration cycle is proposed in which the waste heat from an ejector-expansion trans-critical CO2 refrigeration cycle is utilized for power production and water purification simultaneously. The waste heat utilization was performed by means of a CO2 supercritical power cycle and a desalination system for pure water production. In order to run the desalination system, an absorption heat transformer is employed to upgrade the lower temperature waste heat. Thermodynamic models are developed for both the ejector-expansion trans-critical CO2 cycle and the combined cogeneration cycle consisting of all the above mentioned cycles. A parametric study is conducted to investigate and optimize the performance of each cycle under various operating conditions. It is found that, at the optimum conditions, the energy efficiency ratio of combined cogeneration cycle is about 13–45% higher than the coefficient of performance of the ejector-expansion trans-critical CO2 cycle. It is also concluded that, as the gas cooler temperature increases, the pure water production rate in the combined cogeneration cycle is increased.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Carbon dioxide is a safe, economic and environmentally friendly refrigerant, which can be used in the heat pumps and refrigeration systems. Research into the performance and benefits of trans-critical refrigeration cycles using carbon dioxide began in the early 1990s.1,2 Since then, refrigeration systems using CO2 as the refrigerant has attracted the attention of researchers. A particular drawback of these systems is having low efficiency due to a high compressor discharge pressure.3 In recent years, some efforts have been made to enhance the performance of these cycles. Employing an ejector in the CO2 trans-critical cycles has been reported to be beneficial as some part of CO2 expansion occurs in the ejector which would otherwise take place in the throttling valve.4 Another alternative way to enhance the performance of trans-critical refrigeration cycles is to use an expander such as turbine for expansion process to provide some part of the required compressor work.5 Also in order to enhance the cycle performance and make sure that no liquid enters the compressor, some works have been published in using an internal heat exchanger (IHE).6,7 Some experimental works on simultaneous employment of the ejector and the IHE in the trans-critical CO2 cycle have been carried out by Nakagawa et al.,8,9 who reported an improvement of coefficient of performance (COP) by up to 26% when a proper design of internal heat exchanger is used in the system. These authors also stated that the COP could reduce by as much as 10% if an improper sizing of mixing length is used in the ejector. Another enhancement in the performance of ejector-expansion trans-critical CO2 (ETRCC) cycle can be made through using a two-stage compressor with an intercooler as reported in the literature.4,10,11

For thermodynamic reasons, in the TRCC refrigeration cycles, the circulating CO2, which has to be compressed in the compressor, must be cooled in the gas cooler after compression process. A typical temperature range of working fluid entering the gas cooler is around 100–200 °C,3,10,11 which should be cooled down to about 35–55 °C in this component. This provides a considerable amount of thermal energy, which would otherwise be dissipated.12,13 This thermal energy is an ideal source to be used in a supercritical CO2 cycle for power production.14,15 In this respect, Yari et al. in two papers analyzed the utilization of gas cooler waste heat for power production by means of a supercritical CO2 power cycle.16,17 In a novel configuration of ETRCC refrigeration cycle, which is proposed by Yari and Sirousazar,16 it was reported that some energy was still wasted in the gas cooler. Depending on the process design conditions, this wasted energy can be at a temperature of around 75–85 °C in some cases.

This study describes research that follows on from the authors’ previously published research work.16 A new combined cycle is proposed to utilize the waste heat rejected in the gas cooler for power and pure water production. To accomplish the process, the low grade waste heat from the gas cooler is upgraded by an absorption heat transformer (AHT) so that a higher temperature heat source (at about 100–120 °C) is available for desalination purposes. Recently, researchers have focused their attention on the AHT, which upgrades low temperature heat sources to be used for desalination purposes.18–20

In this study, comprehensive thermodynamic analysis and optimization for both the ETRCC cycle and the proposed combined cogeneration (CC) cycle is performed. A parametric study is carried out to identify the effects of various design parameters on the cycle performance. More attention is paid to study the influences of compressor discharge pressure, gas cooler outlet temperature and evaporator temperature on the COP and pure water production rate of the CC cycle. Finally, the two cycles were optimized thermodynamically using the EES (Engineering Equation Solver) software.21

sec.title: Ejector expansion TRCC cycle
sec.p:
The ETRCC cycle with an internal heat exchanger includes a compressor (C), a gas cooler (GC), an internal heat exchanger (IHE), an ejector (EJ), a vapor–liquid separator (SEP), an evaporator (EV) and an expansion valve as shown in Figure 1. The P–h diagram of the cycle is presented in Figure 2. As indicated in these figures, the CO2 at sub-critical pressure, Ps enters the compressor (state 1) and is compressed to the pressure of PGC in the compressor with an isentropic efficiency of ηc. The compressed fluid is then cooled in two stages; in the GC and in the IHE. The flow exiting the IHE (state 3) enters the ejector nozzle and expands with a nozzle isentropic efficiency of ηn. The saturated vapor stream (state 7) is sucked from the evaporator and enters the ejector as secondary flow. These two streams are mixed in the ejector at constant pressure and form the mixture corresponding to the state 4. The mixture is then compressed through the ejector diffuser with an isentropic efficiency of ηd. The two-phase flow leaving the ejector (state 5) enters the vapor–liquid separator where it is divided into saturated liquid (state 5l) and saturated vapor (state 5g) streams. The former stream expands in the expansion valve to a pressure of PEV and the latter stream flows through the IHE where it is superheated before going back to the compressor (state 1). Figure 1.
Schematic diagram of ETRCC cycle with IHE.
ETRCC: ejector-expansion trans-critical CO2; IHE: internal heat exchanger.
Figure 2.
P–h diagram of ETRCC cycle with IHE.
ETRCC: ejector-expansion trans-critical CO2; IHE: internal heat exchanger.

sec.title: Combined cogeneration cycle
sec.p:
The proposed combined cogeneration cycle (CC cycle) is shown in Figure 3. In this system the rejected heat in the gas cooler is utilized for power production and water purification. Figure 3 shows that the compressed CO2 exiting the compressor (state 2), flows into the vapor generator (VG) where it provides the required heat for the supercritical CO2 power cycle. Depending on design conditions, the temperature of carbon dioxide at the VG exhaust (state 12) is around 75–85 °C.16 The thermal energy available at this temperature is upgraded (to around 100–120 °C) by means of an AHT and then is used in a desalination system as indicated in Figure 3. The CO2 exiting the VG, after getting heated by the steam in the auxiliary condenser (Aux. CO), is divided into two streams. One goes to the generator (GE) and the other flows to the evaporator of the absorption heat transformer (AHT EV). These two streams are then combined with each other before flowing through the gas cooler (GC) where it is cooled down to around 35–55 °C. The cooled CO2 at this state flows to the IHE and is cooled further to state 3. All the other processes are the same as those explained above for the conventional ETRCC cycle. Figure 3.
Schematic diagram of the CC cycle.
CC: combined cogeneration.

The processes of the supercritical CO2 power cycle are as follows.
A constant-pressure heat absorption process in the VG (process 9−10).
An expansion process in the turbine with an isentropic efficiency of ηt (process 10−11).
A constant-pressure heat rejection process in the condenser (process 11−8).
A compression process in the pump with an isentropic efficiency of ηp (process 8−9).

The AHT system consists of a generator (GE), an absorber (AB), an evaporator (AHT EV), a condenser (AHT CO), two pumps, an expansion valve and a heat exchanger (ECO). In this system heat is transferred to the working fluid (LiBr/H2O) in the evaporator and the generator while the system rejects heat from its absorber and condenser. The rejected heat in the absorber (at a temperature of around 100–120 °C) is utilized to provide the required energy for the desalination system as indicated in Figure 3. The sequence of processes in the AHT system is as follows: the weak LiBr/H2O solution (with lower concentration of LiBr) from the absorber goes to the generator via the ECO and the expansion valve. As heat is transferred from CO2 to the solution in the (GE), superheated water vapor and strong solution is generated in the (GE). The superheated vapor (state 22) then enters the condenser where it is condensed to the saturated liquid (state 23) before being pumped to the AHT evaporator. The strong solution (state 29) is pumped to the absorber via a solution heat exchanger. The water is first heated by the CO2 in the AHT evaporator to the saturated vapor (state 25) and then flows to the absorber where it is absorbed by the strong LiBr/H2O solution coming back from the generator (state 31) as mentioned above. The heat of absorption released in the absorber is at a temperature of about 100–120 °C. This upgraded energy now can be used as an input for water purification system as suggested in Figure 3.

The water purification system consists of an auxiliary condenser (Aux. CO), a vapor–liquid separator (SEP) and a pump. This system receives its required thermal energy from the absorber of the AHT system as shown in Figure 3. The impure water is heated in the absorber until it is partially evaporated. The two-phase flow enters the SEP where it is separated into liquid and vapor. The liquid phase returns to the suction pump meanwhile the vapor phase passes through the auxiliary condenser where its latent heat is transferred to the CO2 as mentioned above and therefore, the pure water is produced.

sec.title: Thermodynamic analyses
sec.p: Thermodynamic models are developed for the ETRCC and the proposed CC cycles. In the models, each component of the systems has been treated as a control volume for which the principles of mass and energy conservation are applied. Solution of these equations together with the thermodynamic property relations in the EES software simulates the cycle performances.

sec.title: Assumptions
sec.p:
The following assumptions are made in this study.
The systems are simulated under steady-state conditions.
The changes in kinetic and potential energies are neglected.17
The pressure drops in all heat exchangers and connecting pipes are neglected.16,24
The refrigerant leaving the evaporator is assumed as the saturated vapor.17
The flow through the expansion valves is isenthalpic.22
The flow inside the ejector is one dimensional.17
The mixing process in the ejector occurs at constant pressure (evaporator pressure) assuming that the flow momentum in the ejector is conserved.16,23
The turbine and the pumps have isentropic efficiencies.17
Some appropriate effectiveness values are assumed for the IHE and the ECO.16
In the AHT, it is assumed that the solution at the generator and absorber outlets and also the refrigerant at the condenser and the evaporator outlets are saturated.24
The evaporator and generator of the AHT work at the same temperature.24,25 This leads to a higher pure water production rate by means of the desalination system.25
The vapor exiting the separator condenses completely.25
The temperatures of the cooling streams entering the GC (T16), AHT CO (T32) and CO (T20) are assumed to be the same as that of the environment (T0).16,25

Table 1 summarizes the list of input parameters in simulating the ETRCC and CC cycles according to the stream numbers shown in Figure 3. Table 1.
The input data in the simulation.
Parameters Value
P0 (kPa) 100
T0 (∘C) 15–25a,b
TEV (∘C) −25 to 0
TCO (∘C) T0 + 5a,b
TGC (∘C) 35–55c
T10 (∘C) T2–10a,b
PVG (MPa) 8–14c
P9 P9=PVGc,d
m·5 (kg/s) 1
ηP,C (%) 0.9343–0.04478 (P2/P1)a,c
ɛIHE (%) 85d
ηd,ηn (%) 80d
ηp (%) 80b
ηt (%) 85b
T12 (∘C) 75–85
T14 (∘C) T12–10
TGE (∘C) T14–3e
TAHTEV=TGE T14–3e
ɛECO (%) 80e
a
Wang et al.15 b
Cayer et al.14 c
Yari and Mahmoudi.17 d
Yari;10 Yari and Sirousazar.16 e
Gomri.26

Based on the above mentioned assumptions and considering the conservation of mass and energy, thermodynamic relations for each component of the cycles are developed under steady-state condition. The details of these equations have been recently published by the authors.16,17,25

sec.title: Performance evaluation
sec.p: The performance of ETRCC cycle is evaluated by COP, which is defined as the ratio of cooling capacity to power consumed in the compressor12 (1)COP=Q·EVW·c For the case of CC cycle, energy efficiency ratio (EER) is a criterion which assesses its performance. The EER can be defined as follows17,25,27 (2)EER=Q·EV+Q·ABW·in where Q·EV and Q·AB are the heat loads in the evaporator of the refrigeration cycle and the absorber of the AHT system, respectively. The former is the output cooling capacity and the latter is the heat delivered to the water purification subsystem for desalination purposes. Q·AB is the useful part of the input energy to the AHT cycle. In equation (2), W·in is the net power consumed by the cycle which can be calculated as (3)W·in=W·c+W·pumps-W·t Ejector entrainment ratio, U, is a key performance factor. The entrainment ratio is a dimensionless parameter and is defined as the ratio of secondary mass flow rate to the primary mass flow rate of the ejector (4)U=m·7m·3 In this study, throughout the parametric study the mass flow rate of combined flow exiting the ejector is kept constant at 1 kg/s. For this value of combined flow rate, the ejector primary and secondary mass flow rates are 1/(1 + U) and U/(1 + U) kg/s, respectively.

For the AHT system the coefficient of performance (COPAHT) is a measure of its ability to upgrade the thermal energy given to the generator and the evaporator of the system. It is defined as follows24 (5)COPAHT=Q·ABQ·GE+Q·AHTEV Another important parameter in designing and optimizing the AHT system is the flow ratio (f) defined as the ratio of the strong solution mass flow rate to the refrigerant mass flow rate: (6)f=m·29m·22=X28X29-X28 where X is the LiBr concentration in the solution.
The heat loads of the absorber and generator as a function of flow ratio can be calculated through the following equations24 (7)qAB=Q·ABm·25=(f+1)h26-fh31-h25 (8)qGE=Q·GEm·22=h22+fh29-(f+1)h28

sec.title: Optimization method
sec.p: The results obtained from the parametric analysis reveal that the optimum value of coefficient of performance or energy efficiency ratio can be expressed as a function of the five design/operating parameters, as shown below (9)MaximizeCOP/EER(PVG,TGC,TEV,T12,T0)

Subject to: (10)8≤PVG (MPa)≤14 (11)35≤TGC (∘C)≤55 (12)-25≤TEV (∘C)≤0 (13)75≤T12 (∘C)≤85 (14)15≤T0 (∘C)≤25 Using direct search method and applying the constraints on each variable by setting the bounds, the performances of ETRCC and CC cycles are optimized by the EES software. The direct search method is based on a successive search intended to find an extremum by directly comparing the function values at a sequence of trial points without involving derivatives. This method is deemed suitable for problems involving simulation-based optimization or optimizing non-numerical functions, as well as, the problems involving non-smooth or discontinuous functions.25

sec.title: Model validation
sec.p:
For the case of the ETRCC and supercritical CO2 cycles, the model is validated using the previously published data by Deng et al.28 and Cayer et al.29 The simulation model for AHT cycle is validated using the results reported by Rivera et al.30 For comparison purposes, the conditions and assumptions used in Deng et al.,28 Cayer et al.29 and Rivera et al.30 are applied in the model validation. Figure 4 shows the comparison between the results obtained from the present work with those reported previously in the literature. The figures show good agreement between the results for ETRCC, supercritical CO2 and AHT cycles. Figure 4.
Validation of the simulation models: (a) ETRCC cycle; (b) supercritical CO2 power cycle; (c) AHT cycle.
ETRCC: ejector-expansion trans-critical CO2; AHT: absorption heat transformer.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
Figure 5(a) shows the effect of compressor discharge pressure (vapor generator pressure) on the COP for the ETRCC cycle and on the EER for the CC cycle. This figure indicates higher values of EER for the CC cycle compared to the COP of the ETRCC cycle. However, the amount of enhancement is more pronounced at higher compressor discharge pressure. The enhancement can be up to around 29%. Figure 5(a) also indicates that the COP and EER go up first to the maximum values and then decrease. Therefore, the compressor discharge pressure needs to be optimized to yield maximum COP and EER. This is due to the divergent nature of the isotherms in the supercritical region.11 Also, this can be explained if we consider the results shown in Figure 5(b). Referring to this figure, the slope of variation in cooling capacity (Q·EV) at lower values of PVG is higher than that at higher values of PVG. However, the increase of W·in with PVG occurs with a constant slope. Noting that the Q·AB does not change much with PVG, the variation of EER with PVG is justified. This result is in agreement with the previously published data.8,16 Figure 5.
Effects of compressor discharge pressure on the cycles’ parameters: (a) COP and EER; (b) heat loads and power for the CC cycle.
COP: coefficient of performance; EER: energy efficiency ratio; CC: combined cogeneration.

The effects of evaporator temperature on the COP of ETRCC cycle and on the EER of the CC cycle are presented in Figure 6(a). This figure depicts a higher value of EER for the CC cycle compared to the COP of the ETRCC cycle at any given value of evaporator temperature. The figure also shows that the COP and EER increase with increasing evaporator temperature. This is due to the fact that an increase in the evaporator temperature results in a lower pressure ratio across the compressor and consequently a reduced value of compressor and hence net input power (W·in) as shown in Figure 6(b). In addition, Figure 6(b) indicates that as TEV increases the cooling capacity decreases. However, the reduction in the net input power dominates the decrease in the cooling capacity. Figure 6.
Effects of evaporator temperature on the cycles’ parameters: (a) COP and EER; (b) heat loads and power for the CC cycle.
COP: coefficient of performance; EER: energy efficiency ratio; CC: combined cogeneration.

The variations of COP and EER for the ETRCC and CC cycles with gas cooler outlet temperature are shown in Figure 7(a). The figure indicates that, as the gas cooler outlet temperature increases the COP and EER decrease. This trend is mainly related to the decrease in the cooling capacity of evaporator due to an increase in TGC as shown in Figure 7(b). This figure also indicates that the net input power does not increase significantly in comparison with the Q·EV, while TGC increases. Figure 7.
Effects of gas cooler outlet temperature on the cycles’ parameters: (a) COP and EER; (b) heat loads and power for the CC cycle.
COP: coefficient of performance; EER: energy efficiency ratio; CC: combined cogeneration.

Figure 8(a) shows the effect of vapor generator outlet temperature, T12, on the EER of CC cycle at two different values of vapor generator pressure. The figure shows that as the T12 increases the energy efficiency ratio initially increases rapidly and then decreases smoothly. This kind of variation is mainly due to the variation of heat load in the AHT absorber (Figure 8(b)), so that, a change in T12 affects the input energy to the AHT system and consequently the temperatures (and pressures) of the evaporator and the generator of the AHT system. It should also be noted that at constant values of TEV, TGC and PVG, the cooling capacity in the evaporator is constant and the variation of W·in with increasing T12 is very small, as depicted in Figure 8(b). Figure 8.
Effects of vapor generator outlet temperature on the CC cycle parameters: (a) EER; (b) heat load and power.
EER: energy efficiency ratio; CC: combined cogeneration.

The variation of pure water production mass flow rate with vapor generator outlet temperature at different values of TGC and PVG, is shown in Figures 9 and 10, respectively. As indicated in Figure 9, for a given value of T12, increasing the TGC results in an increase of pure water mass flow rate. This is due to the fact that as the TGC increases, the entrainment ratio decreases due to the increase of the ejector backpressure.12 A lower entrainment ratio leads to a higher mass flow rate of CO2 at state points 3 and 13 and consequently a higher input thermal energy to the AHT system through the absorber and the evaporator (the ejector outlet mass flow rate has been considered constant). This higher input energy will in turn lead to a higher heat rejection in the absorber which results in a higher pure water production rate. Similar variations are detected for pure water mass flow rate as T12 and PVG change (Figure 10). Figure 9.
The effects of vapor generator and gas cooler outlet temperatures on the pure water production rate.
Figure 10.
The effects of vapor generator outlet temperature and compressor discharge pressure on the pure water production rate.

Figure 11 depicts the influence of evaporator temperature on the pure water production rate for the CC cycle. The figure shows that, as the evaporator temperature increases water production rate decreases. This is due to the reduction in CO2 mass flow rate passing through the generator and evaporator of the AHT cycle which in turn leads to a lower energy input to this system. Figure 11.
The effects of evaporator temperature on pure water production rate.

The effect of absorber temperature on its heat load and on the COP of the AHT system is shown in Figure 12. Referring to this figure, at higher values of TAB, both the COPAHT and the absorber heat load decrease. This is due to the fact that as the absorber temperature increases, the concentration of weak solution and consequently the flow ratio (f) increases resulting in a decrease of the absorber heat load and the COPAHT.24 This result is in agreement with the previously published data.18 However, at absorber temperatures of less than 112 °C both the performance parameters are almost constant. Figure 12.
Effect of the absorber temperature on its heat load and the COPAHT.

The variation of pure water production rate with the absorber temperature is shown in Figure 13, which shows a trend similar to that of Figure 12, i.e. decreasing pure water production rate at higher absorber temperatures. Figure 13.
Effect of the absorber temperature on the pure water production rate.

The influence of environment temperature on the EER of CC cycle is presented in Figure 14, which reveals that, at a given value of T12, the EER is reduced as T0 increases. It can be argued that, as T0 increases, the condenser temperatures in both the supercritical CO2 power cycle and in the AHT cycle are also increased. Increasing the condenser temperature causes in a lower power production in the supercritical CO2 power cycle and a lower COPAHT in the AHT cycle (Figure 4(c)). A lower COPAHT means a lower heat load in the absorber (Q·AB). Also the effect of T0 on cooling capacity, net input power and pure water production rate of the CC cycle is depicted in Figure 15, which indicates that as T0 increases, the net input power and pure water production rate are increased while the cooling capacity remains constant. The increase in net input power and water production are due to the lower value of power production in the supercritical CO2 cycle and the lower heat load in the absorber of the AHT cycle, respectively, as mentioned above. Figure 14.
Effect of the environmental temperature on the EER of the CC cycle.
EER: Energy efficiency ratio.
Figure 15.
Effect of environmental temperature on cooling capacity, net power consumed and pure water production rate.

Using the direct search method, the coefficient of performance of the ETRCC cycle and the energy efficiency ratio of the CC cycle are optimized. In order to make the results more realistic, the optimization procedure is performed for a given value of cooling capacity (Q·EV=100kW) at an evaporator temperature of TEV=0∘C. The results are outlined in Tables 4 and 5. Table 4.
The results of optimization for maximum COP of the ETRCC cycle.
TGC (∘C) PGC (MPa) COP m·5 (kg/s) T2 (∘C)
35 8.424 3.377 1.076 100.6
40 9.501 2.728 1.111 115.8
45 10.51 2.290 1.147 129.5
50 11.45 1.973 1.183 142.0
55 12.33 1.731 1.220 153.5
T0=15∘C,TEV=0∘C,Q·EV=100kW.
COP: coefficient of performance; ETRCC: ejector-expansion trans-critical CO2.
Table 5.
The results of optimization for maximum EER of the CC cycle.
TGC (∘C) PVG (MPa) T12 (∘C) EER m·5 (kg/s) m·purewater (kg/h)r T2 (∘C)
35 8.485 76.54 3.837 1.068 12.77 101.5
40 9.749 76.35 3.278 1.085 15.57 119.0
45 11.27 76.19 2.935 1.089 19.68 138.1
50 12.58 76.16 2.704 1.107 23.79 153.9
55 13.36 76.13 2.512 1.148 26.59 164.1
TEV=0∘C,T0=15∘C,TAB=110∘C,Q·EV=100kW.
EER: energy efficiency ratio; CC: combined cogeneration.

As indicated in the tables the optimum compressor discharge pressure is slightly higher for the case of CC cycle compared to that for the ETRCC cycle. Also, with decreasing gas cooler outlet temperature, the COP and EER of cycles are increased. In addition, Table 5 shows that as the gas cooler outlet temperature increases the pure water production rate grows up.

A comparison between Tables 4 and 5 reveals that the maximum EER, under optimized condition, for the CC cycle is around 13–45% higher than the maximum COP for the ETRCC cycle. However, this enhancement is higher at higher gas cooler outlet temperatures.

Finally, based on the results indicated in Table 5, it can be concluded that, under the optimum conditions in the CC cycle, a maximum pure water production flow rate of 26.59 kg/h is achieved. Considering 10 L of fresh water per day to be used by a typical residential31 the produced pure water will be enough for more than 60 residential units.

In order to investigate the sensitivity of the optimization results, for the CC cycle, to the vapor generator pressure (PVG) and vapor generator outlet temperature (T12), a sensitivity analysis is performed and the results are shown in Figure 16. For this purpose, the PVG and T12 are increased and decreased by ±2%, ±4% and ±6% from the reference values and 7 discrete points are obtained. Then, these 7 values are introduced into the optimization program in order to obtain the optimal solutions. The results indicated in Figure 16 reveals that the sensitivity of the EER to the PVG is greater than that for the T12. Figure 16.
The influence of the vapor generator pressure and outlet temperature on the optimal results.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
In this article, a CC system is proposed and analyzed for waste heat recovery from the ETRCC refrigeration cycle. An investigation of the operating parameters on the performance of the ETRCC and CC cycles yielded some important insights to the plant operation. Some key findings of the present study can be listed as follows.
Under the optimized conditions, the energy efficiency ratio of the CC cycle is around 13–45% higher than the coefficient of performance of the ETRCC cycle with IHE.
The COP and EER of both cycles are increased with decreasing gas cooler outlet temperature and/or increasing evaporator temperature.
The optimum compressor discharge pressure (and temperature) for the best performance in the CC cycle is slightly higher than those in the ETRCC cycle.
Increasing the gas cooler outlet temperature results in an increase of pure water production rate in the CC cycle.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research was funded by the University of Mohaghegh Ardabili.
